Part A | The Landscape


Lets begin with a question: what should we choose when we can't have everything?


It turns out that when we view any choice as costing us the value of our next best option, relying on others can be good for everyone simultaneously. To show this we build a model of opportunity cost, the production possibility fronteir, and comparative advantage, asking: Where on the PPF should we live?


This question is where economic thinking began and makes up many of the puzzles at the heart of how we organize society. And it's exactly where we're headed in this course.



Part B | Coordination With Prices


Weâ€™ve set the scope of what's possible, and that simply organizing our decisions according to comparative advantage can improve everyone. But we're left with the question of how to choose where on the PPF to live. We'll turn to prices to help answer that question, giving us a device to coordinate choices across buyers and sellers.



Part C | Government Policies


Markets can allow us to coordinate, but how do they distribute the gains from exchange to buyers and sellers? Here, we'll develop a simple measure of how the market rewards both sides of the market, and how government policies (like taxes and price controls) can redistribute welfare, and how these policies impact overall effeciency.



Part D | Market Failures


Unfortunately, the model of markets we've used is incomplete. This week we will look at market failure: situations where markets fail to maximize surplus value.


Externalities are one example of a market failure within the market model: a cost or benefit impacting those not directly participating in the market. Externalities can be positive (e.g. a vaccine) or negative (e.g. carbon emissions).

The solution to this problem is to get the people creating the externality to take the costs or benefits their actions create into account when they make their choices. Economists call this internalizing the externality and we'll look at a few options.


We'll also look at a particular type of externality present in goods that are rival but not-excludable: common resources. To do this requires a bit of game theory, which we'll pair with a simulation to capture some of the frustration involved with common resources.



Part E | Sellers


Next we turn to seller's profit maximization decision, "The Firm's Problem" in markets more realistic than the model of perfect competition we've used so far.

Asking how firms make choices requires (unfortunately in my mind) doing some cost accounting. Cost curves come from the relationship between inputs and outputs, and we'll discuss the important relationships between these curves.

We can then use the firms costs to return to our familiar model of supply and demand in competitive markets from the perspective of the seller's costs and benefits. This allows us to solve the firm's profit maximization decision, "The Firm's Problem", in markets more realistic than the model of perfect competition we've used so far.


Armed with these tools we can look at markets with one, few, or many sellers, selling in markets with homogeneous or branded goods.
